{{good article}} {{Nutritional value | name = TenderGrill chicken sandwich | image = [[File:TenderGrill 2013.JPG|250px]] | caption = The North American version of the
TenderGrill sandwich, as of November 2013. | serving_size = 1 sandwich (425 g) | kcal = 510 | opt1n = Energy from fat | opt1v = {{convert|124|kcal|kJ|abbr=on}} | fat = 19 g | satfat = 3.5 g | transfat = 0.5 g | opt2n = Cholesterol | opt2v = 75 mg | sodium_mg = 1180 | carbs = 49 g | fiber = 0 g | sugars = 15 g | protein = 37 g | source = [http://www.bk.com/Nutrition/PDFs/brochure.pdf www.BK.com (PDF)] | note = May vary outside US market. }} International fast-food restaurant chain [[Burger King]] and its Australian franchise [[Hungry Jack's]] have had a variety of grilled chicken sandwiches in their product portfolio since 1990. The '''BK Broiler''' was the first iteration, and was one of the most successful product introductions in the fast food industry to that point in time. However sales dropped in the following two years, and the product was reformulated and renamed to the '''Chicken Whopper''' to align the product with the company's [[Whopper]] Sandwich. A change of ownership of Burger King in 2004 prompted another reformulation of the product into the '''BK Baguette''' product line that focused on a more health-oriented product. This new formulation proved unpopular and was replaced in 2005 with the '''TenderGrill''' chicken sandwich. The TenderGrill sandwich was introduced as part of a series of sandwiches designed to expand Burger King's menu with both more sophisticated, adult oriented fare and present a larger, meatier product that appealed to 24- to 36-year-old males. Burger King was the first major fast food chain to introduce a grilled chicken sandwich to the marketplace, beating rivals [[Wendy's]] by six months and [[McDonald's]] by four years. These two chains also went through a series of reformulations and naming schemes for their grilled chicken products. The company sells slightly different versions of the sandwich between international markets, using white meat chicken breast in some regions while using dark meat chicken thighs in others. To promote continuing interest in the product, Burger King occasionally releases limited-time (LTO) variants on its grilled chicken sandwiches that have different ingredients from the standard sandwich recipe. Being one of the company's major offerings, the grilled chicken sandwich is sometimes the center of product advertising for the company. Additionally, as a major product in the company's portfolio, Burger King has registered many global trademarks to protect its investment in the product. ==History== === BK Broiler === Burger King's first broiled chicken sandwich was introduced in 1990 and was called the BK Broiler.{{cite news |url=http://business.highbeam.com/409700/article-1G1-8829375/franchisees-bk-kid-club-took-so-long |title=Franchisees on BK Kid's Club: what took so long? |last=Carlino |first=Bill |date=30 March 1990 |work=Nation's Restaurant News |accessdate=6 June 2009 |type=subscription required}}{{cite news |title=Fitzjohn Navigates Careful BK International Growth |last=Bernstein |first=Charles |date=15 May 1995 |work=Restaurants & Institutions Magazine |publisher=Reed Business Information |accessdate=3 June 2009}} This sandwich was made with lettuce, tomato and a dill ranch sauce served on an [[oat]] dusted roll.{{cite news |last=Burros |first=Marian |title=Fast Food Chains Try to Slim Down |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/11/garden/eating-well-fast-food-chains-try-to-slim-down.html?scp=10&sq=BK+Broiler&st=cse&pagewanted=all |accessdate=23 September 2011 |newspaper=New York Times |date=11 April 1990}} The product came at a time of fundamental change in terms of chicken product in the restaurant industry; more than 90% of chicken products sold by the major chains were fried. Shortly after its introduction, the sandwich was selling more than a million units per day, and poaching sales from traditional fried chicken chains such as [[Kentucky Fried Chicken]].{{cite news |last=Ramirez |first=Anthony |title=Getting Burned By the Frying Pan |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/20/business/getting-burned-by-the-frying-pan.html?scp=7&sq=BK+Broiler&st=cse&pagewanted=all |accessdate=23 September 2011 |newspaper=New York Times |date=20 March 1990}} Additionally, the sandwiches were part of an industry trend towards the diversification of menus with healthier products such as reformulated cooking methods and salads.{{cite news |last=Burros |first=Marian |title=The Slimming Of Fat Fast Food |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/25/garden/eating-well-the-slimming-of-fat-fast-food.html?scp=1&sq=BK+Broiler&st=cse&pagewanted=all |accessdate=23 September 2011 |newspaper=New York Times |date=25 July 1990}} At the time, the sandwich had 379 calories and 18 grams of fat, 10 of which came from the sauce.{{cite news |last=Burros |first=Marian |title=Weighing In on the Nutrition Scale |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/13/business/weighing-in-on-the-nutrition-scale.html?scp=5&sq=BK%20Broiler&st=cse |accessdate=23 September 2011 |newspaper=New York Times |date=13 March 1991}} The introduction of the BK Broiler was one of the most successful product launches in the restaurant industry at the time, encouraging the company look into introducing additional products that would match the success of the Broiler.{{cite news |last=Ramirez |first=Anthony |title=Fast Food Lightens Up But Sales Are Often Thin |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/19/business/fast-food-lightens-up-but-sales-are-often-thin.html?scp=8&sq=BK+Broiler&st=cse&pagewanted=all |accessdate=23 September 2011 |newspaper=New York Times |date=19 March 1991}} Furthermore, the success of the product was credited by analysts from Shearson Lehman Hutton Securities as one of the main factors helping Burger King realize a 47% increase in profit margin over the same period in 1989.{{cite news |title=Grand Met's Net Up 36% |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/17/business/grand-met-s-net-up-36.html |accessdate=23 September 2011 |newspaper=International Herald Tribune |publisher=New York Times |date=17 May 1990}} By 1992, sales of the BK Broiler had slowed to half of what they were at the height of it introduction.{{cite news |last=Burros |first=Marian |title=Eating Well |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/06/garden/eating-well.html?scp=7&sq=Chicken+Whopper&st=cse&pagewanted=all |accessdate=23 September 2011 |newspaper=New York Times |date=14 May 1992}} The company reformulated the BK Broiler in 1998 into a larger, more male-oriented sandwich served on a [[Whopper]] bun, increasing its patty size while changing the ingredients to mayonnaise, lettuce and tomato. The idea behind the up-sizing of the product was to give the customer a sense of value, with a company spokesman stating "When they [the customer] see a lot, it seems like they're getting a lot for their money, and even if they don't eat it all, they think they're being treated fairly." The move was part of the company's "back to basics" movement in which it reorganized its menu, focusing on its core products and simplifying its product base.{{cite news |last=Lubow |first=Arthur |title=Steal this burger |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/19/magazine/steal-this-burger.html?pagewanted=all |accessdate=23 September 2011|newspaper=New York Times |date=14 April 1998}} === Chicken Whopper === [[File:Chicken Whoppers.JPG|thumb|right|An example of the Chicken Whopper Jr. (left) and the Chicken Whopper.]] As part of the forty-fifth anniversary of its [[Whopper|Whopper sandwich]] in 2002, BK introduced an updated version of the sandwich called the Chicken Whopper and added a smaller version called the Chicken Whopper Jr. sandwich along with a new Caesar salad sandwich topped with a Chicken Whopper filet.{{cite web |editor=Allen, Robin Lee |url=http://business.highbeam.com/409700/article-1G1-84019673/crown-jewels-new-marketing-product-rollouts-energize |title=Crown jewels: New marketing, product rollouts energize BK journey back to fast-food royalty |work=Nation's Restaurant News |date=18 March 2002 |type=subscription required}}{{cite press release |publisher=Burger King Corporation |url=http://www2.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/05-23-2002/0001734302&EDATE= |title=Burger King Sells 40 Millionth Chicken Whopper |date=23 May 2003}}{{cite news |last=Rector |first=Sylvia |title=Chicken rules fast-food roost |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2002-11-06/entertainment/0211060202_1_menu-board-national-chicken-council-panera-bread |accessdate=23 September 2011 |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |date=6 November 2002|agency=Knight Ridder/Tribune}} The introduction of the Chicken Whopper represented the company's first move to extend the Whopper brand name beyond beef-based sandwiches since the original Whopper's introduction in the 1950s.{{cite web |title=Carrols: Chicken Whopper Is A Bust|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/retail-trade/eating-drinking-places/4274163-1.html |work=All Business |publisher=[[Dun & Bradstreet]] |accessdate=23 September 2011 |date=March 2003}} The sandwiches featured a whole chicken breast filet, weighing either {{convert|4.7|oz|g|abbr=on}} for the larger sandwich and a {{convert|3.1|oz|g|abbr=on}} for the Jr., mayonnaise, lettuce, and tomato on a sesame seed roll.{{cite news |last=Hoffman |first=Ken |title=Chicken sandwich grows up to be a Whopper |url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/2002_3535763/chicken-sandwich-grows-up-to-be-a-whopper.html |accessdate=23 September 2011 |newspaper=Huston Chronicle |date=12 April 2002 |page=5}} A newly reformulated low fat mayonnaise was introduced in conjunction with the new sandwiches.{{cite news |last=Wahlgren |first=Eric |title=Burger Makers' Not-So-Meaty Prospects |url=http://www.businessweek.com/bwdaily/dnflash/apr2002/nf2002049_3504.htm |accessdate=24 September 2011 |work=Business Week |date=9 April 2002}} Along with the company's new [[BK Veggie]] sandwich, The Chicken Whopper Jr. version of the sandwich was lauded by the [[Center for Science in the Public Interest]] as being one of the best nutritionally sound products sold by a fast food chain. Conversely, the CSPI decried the rest of the Burger King menu as being vastly unhealthy.{{cite press release |title=CSPI Picks the Best and Worst Fast Foods |url=http://www.cspinet.org/new/200208211_print.html |publisher=Center for Science in the Public Interest |accessdate=24 September 2011 |date=21 August 2002}} Development of the sandwich began in 2001 in response to several major factors.{{cite news |last=Horovitz |first=Bruce |title=Fast-food giants always trying new tastes |url=http://www.usatoday.com/money/general/2002/07/03/fast-food.htm |accessdate=24 September 2011 |newspaper=USA Today |date=3 July 2007}} After an overall sales decline of 17% coupled with a profit decline of 29%, Burger King held a series of consumer tests that showed the company's customer base was looking for a wider variety of options when making purchases. Additional survey results revealed that a lack of newer products was discouraging consumers from visiting the chain. Furthermore, the company was seeking to counter the threat to its sales by newer [[fast casual restaurant]]s that had begun to bite into sales. By July 2002, the chain had sold nearly fifty million of the sandwiches, eventually displacing the BK Broiler's initial launch figures as the company's best selling product introduction.{{cite press release |title=50 Millionth Chicken Whopper Sandwich Will Be Sold Today |url=http://www2.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/07-01-2002/0001756551&EDATE= |publisher=Burger King Corporation |accessdate=23 September 2011 |date=1 July 2002}} The successful introduction of the Chicken Whopper was one of the few noted positive highlights of the company during negotiations for the sale of Burger King by its owner [[Diageo]] to a group of investors led by the [[TPG Capital]]; Chicago-based consulting firm Technomic Inc. president Ron Paul was quoted that he was encouraged by recent product changes at Burger King such as the new Chicken Whopper, but he said it's too early to tell whether the changes have been successful.{{cite news |last=Colliver |first=Victoria |title=Whopper of a Deal |url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2002-07-26/business/17552677_1_goldman-sachs-capital-partners-diageo-plc-burger-king-s-north-american/2|accessdate=24 September 2011 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |date=26 July 2002 |page=2}} Despite the Chicken Whopper's initial success, just over a year after the Chicken Whopper's introduction enthusiasm for the product was waning; Burger King's largest franchisee, [[Carrols Corporation]], was complaining that the product line was a failure, describing the sandwich as a pedestrian product with a great name. As of November 2013, the Chicken Whopper is the current grilled chicken sandwich sold by Burger King in the [[Middle East]].{{cite web |title=Burger King menu - Middle East|url=http://www.burgerkingme.com/menu/localmenu.php |publisher=Burger King |accessdate=1 December 2013 |date=30 November 2013}} With its 2014 expansion in to [[India]], Burger King introduced the Chicken Whopper as one of three versions of the Whopper. The other two variants are the [[Mutton]] Whopper and the Veggie Whopper. === BK Baguette === [[File:BK TenderGrill (new).jpg|thumb |left |2nd US version of the TenderGrill chicken sandwich.]] In 2004, BK introduced its BK Baguette line of sandwiches designed to replace the Chicken Whopper.{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,97477,00.html |title=New Burger King Menu Targets Healthy Eaters |agency=[[Reuters]] |publisher=[[Fox News]] |date=16 September 2003 |accessdate=27 October 2007}}{{cite press release |publisher=Burger King Corporation |url=http://www.junkfoodnews.net/burgerking-chickenbaguette.htm |title=Burger King's New Low-Fat Fire-Grilled Savory Mustard Chicken Baguette |date=June 2002 }} The sandwiches were introduced at the insistence of the new [[CEO]], former [[Darden Restaurants]] executive [[Brad Blum|Bradley (Brad) Blum]], shortly after the company was acquired by [[TPG Capital]] in 2002. The sandwiches were designed to be a lower fat alternative with 5g of fat and 350 or fewer calories.{{cite web |last=Day |first=Sherri |title=Burger King to sell low-fat chicken sandwiches |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/19/business/company-news-burger-king-to-sell-low-fat-chicken-sandwiches.html |work=New York Times |accessdate=17 November 2013 |date=19 September 2003}} The line was a health conscious oriented product that got its taste from ingredients instead of fat. They were formally introduced in 2004 as its BK Baguette line of sandwiches, that replacing the Chicken Whopper sandwiches. The baguette sandwiches were introduced to Europe starting in the UK in 2003, with several new varieties designed to cater to the population mix of the country. While the baguette sandwiches were well received and continue to be sold, several red flags have been raised by the British government and private groups in regards the healthiness of these and other products sold by the fast food industry. In 2005, British [[Food Standards Agency]] (FSA) cited large levels of fats and salt in the company's beef-based Monterey Melt baguette and chided BK for backing out of an agreement to help make the company's products healthier.{{cite web |url=http://verify.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2087-1817439,00.html |title=Burger King opts out of health food drive |first=Jonathan |last=Leake |work=[[The Times]] |publisher=[[News International]] |date=9 October 2008 |accessdate=4 December 2007 |quote=The company has recently suggested its new range of "fresh-baked baguettes" offers a healthier choice. It includes the Monterey Melt which contains 2.3 grams of salt and nearly 600 calories. |location=London}} In 2007 the private public interest group ''Consensus Action on Salt and Health'', abbreviated to CASH, cited Burger King and other fast food chains over the continued levels of sodium contained in these types of foods. The group specifically claimed that the Chicken BLT Baguette sandwich, when paired with fries and a Coca-Cola, was one of the three saltiest fast food products in the UK.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/7050585.stm |title=Fast food salt levels 'shocking' |author= |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=8 October 2007 |accessdate=4 December 2007 |quote=A meal at a fast food restaurant could expose children to "staggeringly" high levels of salt, a survey has suggested.| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071020132157/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/7050585.stm| archivedate= 20 October 2007 | deadurl= no}} {{-}} === TenderGrill === [[File:BK TenderGrill.jpg|thumb|right|The original version of the TenderGrill sandwich.]] The Baguette sandwiches failed to catch on in the American market, and as a result they were discontinued as part of a menu reorganization. In 2005, they were replaced by the TenderGrill sandwich.{{cite news |url=http://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/food/2004-03-21-burgerking_x.htm |title=Burger King zaps menu, image |first=Bruce |last=Horovitz |publisher=USA Today |date=22 March 2004 |accessdate=26 September 2007 |quote=Early on, he pushed a healthier menu that wasn't true to Burger King's core customer. Now, the company is pulling back from its Chicken Baguette sandwiches and their flagging sales. Blum won't deny that baguettes could go.}}{{cite web |url=http://business.highbeam.com/409700/article-1G1-135505394/return-king-bk-recovery-aided-sales-jump-chicken-fries |title=Return of the 'King'? BK recovery aided by sales jump, Chicken Fries |first=Amy |last=Garber |date=22 August 2005 |work=Nation's Restaurant News |type=subscription required}} The new sandwich was one of several products that were designed to appeal to a group of customers Burger King identified as adult males, 24–36 years old that desired a larger, meatier product.{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/7857151/site/newsweek/ |title=A really Big Idea |date=23 May 2006 |accessdate=16 July 2007 |first=Bret |last=Begun |publisher=MSNBC |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061206114440/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/7857151/site/newsweek/ |archivedate=December 6, 2006 }} === Chicken Burger === In December 2015, Burger King introduced the Chicken Burger in the U.S. This sandwich has a patty topped with the standard Whopper toppings of mayonnaise, lettuce, tomato, pickles, ketchup and onion on a toasted brioche bun. {{cite web |url=http://www.bk.com/menu-item/flame-grilled-chicken-burger |title=Flame Grilled Chicken Burger |accessdate=28 December 2015 |date=28 December 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.restaurantnews.com/burger-king-restaurants-introduce-flame-grilled-chicken-burger/? |title=Burger King Restaurants Introduce Flame Grilled Chicken Burger |accessdate=28 December 2015 |date=28 December 2015}} === Competitive products === Similar products from other chains have also been introduced, reformulated and generally been fluid in their presences in the marketplace since 1990. Despite the present day competitive products from multiple vendors, Burger King was the first national fast food chain to bring a broiled chicken sandwich to market, beating rival [[Wendy's]] by a period of several months.{{cite web |last=Ryan |first=Nancy |title=Versatile Chicken Takes Turn On Grill |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1990-10-15/business/9003260402_1_fried-chicken-low-fat-items-grilled |work=Chicago Tribune |accessdate=19 November 2013 |date=15 October 1990}} Wendy's introduced their first grilled chicken product, simply called a grilled chicken sandwich, in August 1990. The sandwich originally was made with grilled chicken on 4-inch bun with lettuce, tomato and a honey mustard sauce.{{cite web |last=Keegan |first=Peter |title=Wendy's grilled-chicken sandwich ready to roll after test flight. |url=http://business.highbeam.com/409700/article-1G1-9269237/wendy-grilledchicken-sandwich-ready-roll-after-test |work=Nation's Restaurant News |accessdate=19 November 2013 |date=30 July 1990 |type=subscription required}} Wendy's introduced a reformualted grilled chicken sandwich in 1996 that they claimed was plumper and juicier.{{cite web|last=Bennett|first=James|title=Political Ads Leap From the TV Landscape|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/14/us/political-ads-leap-from-the-tv-landscape.html|work=New York Times|accessdate=19 November 2013|date=14 October 1996}} Wendy's reformulated their grilled chicken product in 2004 as the Ultimate Chicken Grill sandwich during an overhaul of its chicken sandwich line. As of November 2013, the Ultimate Chicken Grill is still Wendy's main grilled sandwich in the United States.{{cite press release |title=Wendy's Launches Chicken Temptations|url=http://ir.wendys.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=67548&p=irol-wendynewsArticle_pf&ID=1200113&highlight= |publisher=Wendy's Corporation |accessdate=19 November 2013 |date=1 April 2004}}{{cite web |title=Ultimate Chicken Grill |url=http://www.wendys.com/en-us/chicken/ultimate-chicken-grill |publisher=Wendy's Corporation |accessdate=19 November 2013}} While McDonald's had been trying to develop and test a similar product for several years,{{cite web |last=Zuckerman |first=David |title=McDonald's begins test of chicken sandwich. (Chicken LT) |url=http://business.highbeam.com/409700/article-1G1-4144790/mcdonald-begins-test-chicken-sandwich |work=Nation's Restaurant News |accessdate=19 January 2014 |date=24 February 1986}} the company was caught off guard at the time when its mainline competitors introduced their grilled chicken products and was not able to initially deploy a similar product. This was primarily due to the fact the company's highly specialized kitchens could not produce a high quality product without a large investment in new equipment. By early-1991, McDonald's grilled chicken product was still in development,{{cite web |last=Ramirez |first=Anthony|title=Low-Fat McDonald's Burger Is Planned to Answer Critics |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/13/business/low-fat-mcdonald-s-burger-is-planned-to-answer-critics.html |work=New York Times |accessdate=19 November 2013 |date=13 March 1991}} and the vendor would not introduce its version, the McGrilled Chicken Classic, until 1994.{{cite news |title=Big Mac turns 30, but McDonald's refuses to rest |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1755&dat=19980910&id=lEEgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qX0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6877,6313616 |accessdate=19 November 2013 |newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune |page=3D |date=10 September 1998 |agency=Associated Press}} The McGrilled chicken sandwich was replaced with the Grilled Chicken Deluxe sandwich in September and October 1996 as part of [[McDonald's Deluxe line]] of "upscale" sandwiches; the company had hoped that a higher value product would help improve average check performance at its stores.{{cite web |last=Millman |first=Nancy |title=McDonald's Adult Concept Spreading To Fish, Chicken |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1996-09-20/business/9609200304_1_arch-deluxe-sourdough-bun-mcdonald |work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=19 November 2013 |date=20 September 1996}} However, by 1998 the whole Deluxe line was said to be not selling well, and the Grilled Chicken Deluxe was eliminated when McDonald's brought back the Chicken McGrill sandwich back in 1999.{{cite web |title=McDonald's Corporation 1999 Annual Report |url=http://www.mcdonalds.com/content/dam/AboutMcDonalds/Investors/C-%5Cfakepath%5Cinvestors-1999-annual-report.pdf |publisher=McDonald's |accessdate=19 November 2013 |author=McDonald's Corporation |format=PDF |date=15 March 2000}} The Chicken McGrill sandwich was retired in 2005 when the company introduced its new [[McDonald's Premium line|Premium line of products]], which like the TenderCrisp sandwich was targeted to a more adult audience with higher quality ingredients such as natural cheeses and whole leaf lettuce.{{cite web |last=Hoffman |first=Ken |title=McDonald's improves on its chicken sandwiches |url=http://www.chron.com/entertainment/article/McDonald-s-improves-on-its-chicken-sandwiches-1619714.php |work=Huston Chronicle |accessdate=20 November 2013 |date=18 August 2005}} Beginning in April 2015, McDonald's moved to a new grilled chicken sandwich, the Artisan Grilled Chicken; the new chicken uses a smaller list of ingredients in the chicken filet, removing ingredients such as [[maltodextrin]] and [[sodium phosphates]]. The new sandwich is in response to consumer-based market trends of food products that have simpler, more natural ingredients.{{cite web |last1=Choi |first1=Candice |title=McDonald's changing grilled chicken recipe to cut chemical-sounding ingredients |url=http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/taste/298317621.html |publisher=Minneapolis Star Tribune |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=2 April 2015 |date=2 April 2015}} == Product description == The TenderGrill is a [[chicken sandwich]], consisting of a {{convert|5.2|oz|g|abbr=on}} flame-grilled chicken breast filet, mayonnaise, lettuce and tomatoes on an [[brioche]] bun.{{citation |title=Burger King menu - United States |url=http://www.bk.com/en/us/menu-nutrition/lunch-and-dinner-menu-202/fish-and-chicken-221/tendergrill-chicken-sandwich-m2320/index.html |publisher=Burger King |accessdate=1 December 2013}} In some Asian markets, such as Singapore, the filet is made from chicken thigh meat and uses a sesame-seed bun.{{citation |title=Burger King menu - Singapore |url=http://www.burgerking.com.sg/menu/lunch-and-dinner/tendergrill-chicken |publisher=Burger King |accessdate=1 December 2013}} Burger King will also add any condiment it sells upon request based on its long standing slogan "Have It Your Way".{{cite web |last=Dostal |first=Erin |title=The history of Burger King's Whopper |url=http://nrn.com/latest-headlines/history-burger-kings-whopper |work=Nation's Restaurant News |accessdate=6 November 2013 |date=13 December 2012 |type=subscription required}} Additionally, Burger King has sold several different promotional varieties throughout the years as limited time offerings (LTO), such as Chicken Caesar Club, made with [[Romaine lettuce]], [[Parmesan cheese]], [[bacon]] and [[caesar dressing]] on toasted [[sourdough bread]],{{cite press release |url=http://www.junkfoodnews.net/burgerking-saladsandwich.htm |title=Burger King Unveils New 'Salad in a Sandwich' |publisher=Burger King Corporation |date=August 2003}} or the Carolina BBQ TenderGrill made with pepper jack cheese, bacon, jalapeños, red onion and a mustard-based barbecue sauce which was sold during Burger King's 2012 and 2013 Summer BBQ Menu promotions.{{cite press release |title=Burger King Fires Up New Summer BBQ Menu |url=http://finance.yahoo.com/news/burger-king-r-fires-summer-140220739.html |work=Yahoo Finance |publisher=Burger King |accessdate=17 November 2013 |date=21 May 2013}}{{cite web |last=Dostal |first=Erin |title=How McRib comparisons may impact BK Rib's success |url=http://nrn.com/quick-service/how-mcrib-comparisons-may-impact-bk-ribs-success |work=Nation's Restaurant News |accessdate=17 November 2013 |date=16 May 2013}}{{cite press release |title=Burger King Fires Up New Summer BBQ Menu |url=http://bolsa.elperiodico.com/noticias-actualidad/marketwire/en-BURGER-KING-R-Fires-Up-New-Summer-BBQ-Menu--874746001.html |publisher=Burger King Corporation |accessdate=20 November 2013 |date=21 May 2013}} == Advertising == {{see also|Burger King advertising|List of Burger King ad programs}} The BK Broiler was introduced as part of the company's ''Sometimes you gotta break the rules'' campaign designed by the firms of [[D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles]] and [[Saatchi & Saatchi]],{{cite web |last=Jarvis |first=Jeff |title=That's chew business |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,317124,00.html |work=Entertainment Weekly |accessdate=20 November 2013 |date=13 April 2013}}{{cite web |last=Rothenberg |first=Randall |title=Burger King Campaign: 'Break Rules' |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/28/business/the-media-business-advertising-burger-king-campaign-break-rules.html |work=New York Times |accessdate=20 November 2013 |date=28 September 1989}} a campaign that many of Burger King's franchisees derided as ineffectual and unclear in its message.{{cite book |last=Garfield |first=Bob |title=And Now a Few Words From Me |url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id=125313&page=1&singlePage=true |publisher=Good Morning America |isbn=0071441220 |accessdate=20 November 2013 |date=27 July 2004 }} Despite the failure of the advertising campaign, the product went on to be one of the most successful fast food product launches up to that time. The Chicken Whopper was introduced initially via an [[April Fools' Day]] ad in several major news papers that claimed the company was changing its name to "Chicken King". A later press release announced the joke was to introduce the public to the new product.{{cite press release |publisher=Burger King Corporation |title=Got You! Burger King Corporation Plays April Fool's Joke in National Newspaper Ads To Launch New Chicken Whopper Sandwich |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/got-you-burger-king-corporation-plays-april-fools-joke-in-national-newspaper-ads-to-launch-new-chicken-whoppertm-sandwich-76696332.html |date=1 April 1998 |accessdate=21 September 2011}} The television advertising program used to introduce the Chicken Whopper featured animated chickens in cowboy boots marching to the "Have It Your Way" tune and was created by animation house [[Kurtz & Friends]].{{citation |url=http://kurtzanim.wordpress.com/commercials/burger-king/ |title=The marching Chickens |publisher=Kurtz & Friends |accessdate=21 September 2011}} Later commercials featured comedian [[Steve Harvey]].{{cite AV media |people=Steve Harvey |year=2002 |title=Chicken Whopper commercial |trans_title= |medium=Television commercial |accessdate=26 September 2013}} A second series of ads called ''@BK, love is guaranteed'' that were developed by Los Angeles-based ad house Amoeba, guaranteed that customers would receive a free sandwich if they don't "love" the chain's Whopper and Chicken Whopper sandwiches.{{cite web |title=BK guarantees customers will love Whopper, Chicken Whopper |url=http://business.highbeam.com/409700/article-1G1-90702517/bk-guarantees-customers-love-whopper-chicken-whopper |work=Nation's Restaurant News |accessdate=23 September 2011 |author=The Gale Group |date=19 August 2002 |type=subscription required}} With the discovery of mad cow disease by the FDA in 2003, the company instructed their advertising agency at the time, [[Young & Rubicam]] of New York, to retool a forthcoming series of ads featuring the company's signature product, the [[Whopper]], to include the Chicken Whopper. A Burger King spokesman stated that the change was because Burger King "decided that if there's anybody who wants a chicken option, at this point, we wanted to remind them that the Whopper comes in chicken as well as the original beef," noting their confidence in their beef supply.{{cite news |last=Day |first=Sherrie |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2004/01/01/business/a-time-for-finesse-marketing-beef-after-a-mad-cow-discovery.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|title=A Time for Finesse: Marketing Beef After a Mad Cow Discovery|accessdate=23 September 2011 |newspaper=New York Times |date=1 January 2003}} The BK Baguettes line was introduced in the United States via an ad campaign from advertising firm [[Crispin, Porter + Bogusky]] that featured the tagline ''"Flavor from grilling not fat."''{{cite web |last=Crane |first=Dan |title=McNasty |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/life/food/2003/11/mcnasty.html |work=Slate |accessdate=20 November 2013 |date=25 November 2003}}{{cite web |last=Cebrzynski |first=Greg |title=Fire's ready at BK, and its new ad agency probably feels the heat. |url=http://business.highbeam.com/409700/article-1G1-113233201/fire-ready-bk-and-its-new-ad-agency-probably-feels |work=Nation's Restaurant News |accessdate=20 November 2013 |date=9 February 2004}} The American advertising campaigns for the sandwiches featured several celebrity chefs, such as [[Rick Bayless]], visiting locations where similar style food stuffs were found, e.g. a [[farmers' market]], and commenting on how these ingredients make the new Baguette line better and more healthy.{{cite web |url=http://business.highbeam.com/409700/article-1G1-108550259/upscale-chef-bayless-weigh-bk |title=Burger King Corp. hires Rick Bayless to promote new chicken baguette sandwiches |first=Amy |last=Garber |work=Nation's Restaurant News |date=21 September 2003 |accessdate=4 December 2007 |quote=In an unlikely pairing of fine dining and fast food, Burger King Corp. has tapped Chicago chef-restaurateur Rick Bayless to promote BK's new line of low-fat chicken baguette sandwiches. |type=subscription required}} The advertising firm of [[Havas Worldwide|Euro RSCG Leedex]] produced ads for the sandwiches in Great Britain.{{cite web |title=Euro RSCG Leedex lands Burger King baguette business |url=http://www.thedrum.com/news/2004/12/02/euro-rscg-leedex-lands-burger-king-baguette-business |work=The Drum |accessdate=20 November 2013 |date=2 December 2004}} The advertising campaign for the TenderGrill sandwich in Spain in 2010 featured a humor-based ad in which men were asked what type of advertisement would get them to buy the sandwich. The responses, which included what men would like to see in the commercials, formed the basis for the ads.{{cite web |title=Burger King: An ad for guys|url=http://www.adwomen.org/2010/08/burger-king-an-ad-for-guys/ |work=Ad Women |accessdate=20 November 2013 |date=August 2010}} The advertisement, made entirely by women, was filmed in London and featured barbarians, ninjas and unicorns in an advertisement that poked fun at the men's preferences. The making of the commercial was the basis of a mini-documentary from UK firm Feral Films.{{cite web |title=Burger King Chicken Tender Grill |url=http://www.feralfilms.co.uk/burger_king_chicken_tender_grill |publisher=Feral Films |accessdate=20 November 2013 |year=2010}} In a 2011 Singapore campaign, Burger King presented an attack advertisement that was designed to counter the introduction of the Chicken McGrill sandwich from McDonald's. The campaign took McDonald's slogan, ''"Make it better"'' and changed it to ''"Make it even Better"'' and put the sandwich on sale for [[Singapore dollar|SGD]]$1.00 on the same day the McDonald's product was set to debut. Burger King called the McDonald's menu item "fake grilled" as opposed to flame grilled.{{cite web |last=Kang |first=Darryl |title=The King wants to make it even better |url=http://blog.dk.sg/2011/03/10/the-king-wants-to-make-it-even-better/ |accessdate=20 November 2013 |date=10 March 2011}} === Controversies === The 2012 campaign from [[BBDO|Clemenger BBDO]] for the TenderGrill for the Australian Burger King franchise, [[Hungry Jack's]], featured a [[Goth subculture|goth]] girl, complete with facial piercings and tattoos that loses her piercings and tattoos as she eats the sandwich. By the time she has finished her meal, her clothing and style had completely changed – much to her and her friends horror. At the end of the commercial, the announcer states the tag line ''"There is nothing naughty about the new Hungry Jack's TenderGrill ... Hungry Jack's makes it better."'' The [[Advertising Standards Bureau (Australia)|Australian Advertising Standards Bureau]] received several complaints from the public claiming the commercial demeaned alternative lifestyles, was discriminatory and insulting to non-conformists. The Advertising Standards Board determined that the advertisement did not breach any pertinent anti-discrimination codes, and dismissed the complaint.[http://ms.adstandards.com.au/cases/0241-12.pdf Australian Advertising Bureau] case report #0241/12. (27 June 2012), retrieved 20 November 2013.
